barbarabailando: Where do I start... the word “decolonization” says it all. I thought I needed sex ed because my parents could even talk about periods, never mind anything having to do with sex - or even saying the word itself. In my late 20s I finally walked away from hardline evangelicalism after years of experiencing spiritual, sexual, and other types of trauma. In the ensuing years I realized that what I really needed was sex ed that reframed my ENTIRE FUCKING WORLDVIEW. Coming to terms with my sex nature, my body, my own desires, my history, my hurt, my physiological trauma responses... that is the sex education I need and that I’m pursuing. I’m finding that the freedom that comes from the healing is what has unleashed my wildest, most sensual, most sending self. Tips and tricks, that’s all well and good. But the deconstruction of all the beliefs - enculturated patriarchy and Christianity, the unfounded shame, etc. - that is how I am coming into my own. Thank you for this post. You said everything I needed to hear.

foyupdate: My gut reaction to this is: be careful turning people off from being sex educators. As my daughter gets older, I have begun realizing that the school system isn’t going to do a good job with Sex Ed. We live in an abstinence only state with active protests about trans kids using their preferred gender bathroom. I’ve been working on myself and learning about how patriarchal society standards have framed how I see my body and sexuality. I may not be all enlightened nor fully walking the walk yet, but I know I can do a better job than what my kids will get from public schools. And I can be an advocate for organizing and bringing in outside educators for my community. I could even lead some of those talks myself. While I don’t think your comment was aimed at me, I felt like you were telling me I’m not qualified to take a stand for better Sex Ed.

o.inmind: Wonderfully said. I'm sure this post shook many aspiring educators, AND IT SHOULD!
